description: metadata namespace

(target variable) name of the final transformed variable; allowable variable name in SAS, R, JS, TS, Python, Stata
(targert variable) short variable label, less than 15 characters
(target variable) descriptive variable label
major heading
section sub-heading
(target variable) allowable types: cat (categorical), cont (continuous)
unit of variable
variable's role in the algorithm development, validation, deployment, KTE process
the range of values in the original data to be mapped to the target category ('recTo'). The mapping can be one to one (e.g., recFrom = 1 and recTo = 1) or many to one( recFrom = [1,4] and rectTo = 1)

(target variable ) category where Not applicable = `NA::a`;  missing and else categories = `NA::b`. For continuous variables that are not transformed = `copy` (so that the function copies the values without any transformations).
the datasets that contain the variables and categories of interest, separated by commas
(target variable) number of valid categories for the variable
the original names of the variables (as they are listed in the original datasets, separated by commas) that are used to derive the target variables ('variable')
(start variable) allowable types: cat (categoricial), cont (continuous).
the original variable labels (as they are listed in the original datasets)
(target variable) short category label, less than 15 characters
(target variable) descriptive category label. If categories do not change from original data this lable should be the same as 'catStartLabel'
label, from the original variable dataset, describing each category.
Notes give important details  on changes in wording, missing/changes in categories, and changes in variable type that may impact the variable harmonization process across data sets.
reference group (level). Value: TRUE, FALSE, N/A. For 'variables' sheet = reference value.
example: TRUE for female, if females are the reference group.

description: names for the restricted cubic spline variables, separated by semi-colons; allowable variable name in SAS, R, JS, TS, Python, Stata
values for knot locations, separated by semi-colons
name for the centred variable; allowable variable name in SAS, R, JS, TS, Python, Stata
value for centered variable

indicates variable transformation to interaction variable; value, indicated by interactionIndex column, interation1, interaction2, etc. (label is variables separated by _X_ e.g.,variable1_X_variable2)
indicates index value (e.g., 1,2,3...) of interaction variable (i.e., interation1, interaction2, interaction3...)
low value for categorical or continuous level.
low value for categorical or continuous level.
indicates variable transformation of center to mean. TRUE, FALSE (missing treated as false),
indicates log transformation. Value: True, False, NA
indicates variable data cleaning from missing imputed values. value is imputed method. e.g. Hmisc-impute
indicates log transformation. Value: True, False, NA
maximum value for algorithm development
minimum value for algorithm development. If different values for males and females, then algorithm name should be different
method used with `max`. Value: delete, NA (missing), N/A (not applicable), number (real number).
method used with `min`. Value: delete, NA (missing), N/A (not applicable), number (real number).

indicates variable transformation to restricted cubic spline, wehere {num} equals the number of knots. value is rcs_{num}, where {num} indicates number of knots. e.g. rcs_3 for 3-knot restricted cubic spline.
indicates spline transformation. Value: True, False, NA
variable that is recommended user input (versus a variable that is derived from input variables)
mandatory variable required for scoring the algorithm (i.e, can not be missing and replaced with centered value)
